episode: Ep-58 Behind the Tech Kevin Scott Podcast with William A Adams
text:
WILLIAM ADAMS: When you fail, you need someone to say, that’s all right, let’s do it again, right? And this is something that typically, black and women businesses don’t have, right? They struggled to do it once. They get burned. They’re working at McDonald’s, or they’re back to general population. They don’t try again, because they’ve got obligations.
  
KEVIN SCOTT: Hi, everyone. Welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m your host, Kevin Scott, Chief Technology Officer for Microsoft. 

In this podcast, we’re going to get behind the tech. We’ll talk with some of the people who have made our modern tech world possible and understand what motivated them to create what they did. So, join me to maybe learn a little bit about the history of computing and get a few behind-the-scenes insights into what’s happening today. Stick around.

[MUSIC]

CHRISTINA WARREN: Hello, and welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m cohost Christina Warren, Senior Developer Advocate at GitHub.

KEVIN SCOTT: And I’m Kevin Scott.

CHRISTINA WARREN: And today we have a really exciting guest, William Adams. He’s made some really, really important contributions to the field of computer science. And he is also a leader in diversity, equity and inclusion. And he’s won awards and recognition for his work within programming and in D&I stuff, and he just launched a new venture studio aimed to help every Black person interested in having a career in business or technology get into the field. 

So I’m really excited to hear you two talk. I know you have a lot of history with William, Kevin. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, William was one of the first people I recruited into the Office of the CTO when I joined Microsoft, almost seven years ago. And he was an unbelievably valuable member of my team. But maybe more important than that, like William just taught me a ton. Like he was a source of tremendous inspiration. He’s technically amazing, but his determination to go give back to people was absolutely extraordinary.

So I – like I can’t wait to chat with him today. I miss him since he’s been gone from Microsoft, and so it’s always great to catch up. And like hopefully, we can hit on a few of these like inspirational topics, where everybody else can see what inspired me so much about William and the example that he sets for us all. 

KEVIN SCOTT: William Adams is a software engineer, DEI innovator and philanthropist. He founded Adamation, where he developed customer enterprise apps and earned two patents. His contributions to the field there were later documented by the Computer History Museum. William was at Microsoft for more than 20 years and was recognized for rolling out critical XML code globally as well as for cofounding the Leap Apprenticeship Program which was named Microsoft’s D&I Program of the Year in 2020.

About a year ago he left Microsoft to create a venture studio aimed to help every Black person interested in having a career or business in technology get into the field and prosper.

Welcome to the show, William. I’m so glad to have you here today.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Thank you. I’m happy to be here.

KEVIN SCOTT: It feels like it’s been a super-long time. I miss you.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Man! The love is mutual.

KEVIN SCOTT: So we’ve got a ton of stuff to talk about, but I always start the show by asking folks how they got into STEM in the first place. So tell us a little bit about like what lit the spark for you and, you know, we can go from there. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Okay, well, I’m a child of the ‘60s. I was born in 1964, so before all the computer – you know, personal computer stuff and all that. So I started with like the chemistry set, the physics set. And mind you this is all when I was very young. So my mom, when I was probably eight, I said "Hey, let’s go to RadioShack I want to buy one of those electronic kits," right? So I was just kind of self-driven in that way, and it was probably because my dad was a typewriter repair man, so we had stuff in the house, but he passed away when I was seven. So from then on, I was just one of those precocious kids, you know? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. What did your mom do?

WILLIAM ADAMS: My mom was, she worked in Orange County, so she was a County Administrator. She started out as being a welfare – what do you call them? She would check on people who were on welfare. And eventually, she evolved into being, like, the office manager of Orange County. So very, very humble beginnings. You know, my mom was not into STEM. My dad was not into STEM. My dad was actually in World II, you know? He had joined the Navy when he was 16.

KEVIN SCOTT: Wow. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: So you know, there’s no history of STEM and my family other than my uncle, my mom’s brother, and this will come back later in the history. So I just started out as a precocious kid doing wacky stuff on my own. I was very shy. So while other kids were out playing, I would play too, but then at the end of the day, I’m going to go and play with my electronics kit, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: It is interesting. Your parents are almost an ideal combo of values. So your dad was a mechanical tinkerer.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: And like fixed things that people depended on to do their work, and your mother had this –

WILLIAM ADAMS: Social thing.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, and like that’s an interesting combo. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: Like, have you ever thought about the extent to which that influenced some of your thinking about the world? 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Not really, until you just said it now, actually. When I think of my origin story and – you know what really motivated me? I mean, a Black child growing up in the ‘60s, there was plenty around me that was like social justice, this, that and the other thing. But yeah, I hadn’t really thought of the combo like that before. But yeah, that probably – well, it definitely shaped me because, obviously, they were my parents, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: So when did you first become interested in computers?

WILLIAM ADAMS: It was, the exact year escapes me, but it was my uncle said, "I have this Commodore PET," if you want to go back into the annals of history, Chiclets keyboard, cassette tape drive. "I have this kind of PET, would you be interested in it," because he was getting something new. And of course, I’m like, "Yeah!" So for a few months I put pictures of Commodore machines up on my mirror because, like, "It’s coming, some day." So that was the entrée to computers was the Commodore PET, way back then, early ‘70s, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: And what were the first, what was it that attracted you to a personal computer? And like, what sort of programming did you start with? 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Well, the attraction was availability, of course, because no one else in my neighborhood had a computer at that time, right? And this was – by that time, we had moved to the more middle-class neighborhood as opposed to the barrio that we used to live in, but still, no one had computers, because they just weren’t that common, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: But I was a really shy kid, you know, to the point where I couldn’t even tell people my name. I would spell my name out for them with my eyes downcast, rather than say my name. You know, I was just very shy, even though I was in sports and stuff like that. And the computer is just one of those things, right? It’s like you get to tell it what to do. It’s your buddy. It’s your friend. It does what you want, and you interact, and you learn, and you grow. So that’s I think why the connection was made between me and the computer.

The first stuff I did was very low-level machine programming, and by machine, I mean, even before assembly language, right? It’s like you have to encode the instructions by the numbers, you know, and the first things I did were graphics-oriented, put blocks on screens. I mean, this was the time of Pong, right? 

So it’s like, "Oh, let me try to do what Pong does," that sort of thing, 6502 CPU chips.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: And then I think after that there were these books and magazines that had like games, right? Wumpus, Hexapawn, whatever – you know, the little adventure games. So you would type those in and then run the program and make a mistake and have to type the whole thing over again, and maybe save it to cassette. 

So it was games. And then eventually I started fiddling with the hardware. So like I would hook up a joystick to the computer, mess with that, fry an input chip, go to the store, buy another input chip, you know, fry it again. So that sort of thing. So it’s, earliest was just messing around and games. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. I mean, I want to touch on a couple of things that you just said, one of them, which is, you know, just an interesting thing to highlight because I think kids – like I think of my 13-year-old and my 15-year-old, like their mind would be blown by what you just said. So the way that you got to play games is you had this computer that was, by modern measures, like extraordinarily clunky and limited. And the games came to you printed in a magazine.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Printed, in a magazine, and you typed it in.

KEVIN SCOTT: And you type them in, into the computer, and hoped you didn’t make a mistake.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Right.

KEVIN SCOTT: And you got to play the game.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, that – it is kind of wild. I mean, 8k of RAM, and – you know, not very – not even one megahertz CPU, I mean, pretty slow. So you had to be very clever. And they’re – most of them were text-based, but we also had some visuals, you know? If you were really clever about how to program that stuff. 

KEVIN SCOTT: But maybe the more important thing that you just said is, I think it’s extremely important in kids forming an idea of what’s possible, part of it is about access to things that will shape them. And part of it is about role models.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Absolutely.

KEVIN SCOTT: And like being able to sort of see themselves in things. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: And so it was a really extraordinary time, when you were growing up, and when I was growing up, that all of a sudden, this new, interesting thing was accessible. And like making technology accessible to kids, I think is one of the most important things that we all can be doing. And I know it’s something you think a lot about. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, I mean, I thought about – before thinking about this podcast, I was like what about my history? And early on – I mean, I had my uncle. Even before that, when I was like seven or eight, there was this guy in my life, who was named Jackie Robinson, who was a Black dude, who was at UC-Irvine studying computers, and he’d show me printouts of his Fortran programs, and he let me read his book, and it’s like, okay, that was an influence, right? 
And then here’s my uncle, "Here’s your – here’s a computer," okay, that’s an influence. And local to us, we – we lived in the city called Placentia, which is like at that time, a farming community, really, but it was right next to Rockwell International. So all my classmates, at least the white kids, were – their parents were engineers. And Rockwell had a program where they actually brought high school students in for kind of – not an internship, but it was a training program. 

So I learned Fortran, key punch, the rocket equation, you know, calculators, all this stuff. So I was fortunate. I had access. And there it was, right? My circumstance would be completely different if that series of things didn’t exist, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. Well, and I think kids also are so impressionable when they’re young. I mean, I remember my own journey. I got interested in computers, like a) because they were accessible, and b) because videogames seemed fascinating.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: And I just, you know, the thing that I always had from the time I was a like a super-little kid is I just wanted to understand how everything worked. And the more fascinated I was by the thing, the more I wanted to understand how it got made and how it functioned. And like video games were the initial thing that got me into computers, but I remember I got into a science and technology high school when I was a senior, and I did an internship as part of the Computer Science class and I was taking there, where half-a-day a week for six weeks I went to this place and worked with real adult professional engineers. 

And one of them had a copy of Allen Holub’s compiler book, sitting on their desk, and I saw that, and I was like, "This is the most mysterious thing that I’ve ever seen in my life, and I must understand how these programming tools work that I’m using and loving."

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: And like, and that became – like, I was 17 years old, and that became the next 13 years of my life was studying compilers and programming languages. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah. And when you’re young, you don’t know how hard it is.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Like here I am, a 12-year-old kid, and I’m writing – I’m translating machine code. I don’t know if that’s hard or not. I just know how to do it because I read the book and it says, "Do the following," and it’s like, "Oh, okay," right? So it’s like, it’s great to have a plastic mind when you’re young, but that plastic mind needs to be fed with stuff to spark it towards, you know, interesting directions, right? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: So yeah. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Well, so let’s talk about college. And what did you study? And I know like part of your journey is like, not only were you becoming a better and better programmer over time, but like you were thinking about – you know, "How do I become an entrepreneur? Like, how do I make money at this stuff? How do I start businesses? Like what are the useful and interesting things that I can do with this thing that I love?"

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, I have a prop that I wanted to show you that I’m sure you can appreciate. I went to college with this Commodore 64.

KEVIN SCOTT: Nice. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Now, this isn’t the actual one, but I got it off eBay because it’s nostalgic. It’s like, "I’ve got to get one of those again."

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: So I went off to college and Electrical Engineering, Computer Science. And it was interesting at that time, UC-Berkeley, because I remember my math teacher in high school, Dr. Jim Jenkins. He was a guy who had worked on the Manhattan Project, drove to school in a Rolls Royce every day, you know, because he was just giving back to the system, as you said.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: It was public school. He went to UC-Berkeley. So I was inspired. And I went to Berkeley, and he said, "Computer Science? There’s no such thing," you know? So this is 1982, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, and he right, there wasn’t –

WILLIAM ADAMS: That’s right, there wasn’t Computer Science, but you know, they – they had some computers, and you’re programming, DEC PDP-10s, flipping switches, you know, and then eventually they got terminals, and that was the birth of UNIX and all that sort of stuff. But at that time, we were learning – I think I learned Pascal – yeah, I learned Pascal there, and there was this other language called C that you’re supposed to learn on your own, you know, and it was just a heyday of a lot of inventions in – not the internet, but ARPANET, all that stuff was happening then. 

And as college students, we were surrounded. This was in the Bay Area, so we’re surrounded by all these companies popping up. I mean, certainly Apple, you know, and they weren’t as huge as they are today. Adobe, you know, Sun Microsystems, all these companies. So it was just natural for all of us to go, "Okay, I’m going to do startup," right? And it was different from what we think today, right? At that time, we’re like, "I’m going to change the world," and you know, we’re starry-eyed and all that sort of stuff. So my brother and I, you know, he said, "Well, you know how to program. He knows how to sell. Let’s go do that," right? So we just started our first company, Adamation, did some custom software development for the people that owned the building that our office was in, and it just kind of went on from there. 

You know, it was like, "This is just what you do. Let’s go make some money," right? Now, of course, in the early years, we just starved. I mean, quite – we had four employees, and I quite literally, for at least a year or two in there, we had Chip-A-Roo cookies and popcorn for lunch. That’s all we could afford. You’d walk down to the store – Chip-A-Roo cookies, a bag was like a dollar-fifty. Popcorn was maybe a dollar. And I would ride my bike home at night, literally looking in the gutter for a dollar so I could buy a doughnut to have for dinner, right?

It’s like, we’re going – we’re going to do this this thing, that we’re dedicated, right? That’s how it was for a few years, but over time, we actually succeeded. We became big dogs in a little – or big fish in a small pond of NeXT Computers, and then we went on from there, but it was just a natural flow. It’s like, "I’m learning stuff. I know how to program. I’ve got friends who can program. The world is our oyster, let’s go get it," right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Let’s talk a little bit about why NeXT, versus – so again, this is another interesting thing for the young folks. The number of platforms and types of computers and different types of microprocessor instruction set architectures that were out there when you were doing all of this was way more diverse than it is now. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah. 

KEVIN SCOTT: And so, you could have chosen to do a lot of things. You could have done PC software, you could have done MAC software, you could have done like UNIX stuff on a bunch of different UNIX systems that were becoming popular then, but you chose to work on NeXT –

WILLIAM ADAMS: This niche market, NeXT – and that comes from – while I was at UC-Berkeley, I managed the computer store there. And so I was familiar with Apple. So I knew all those people. And you know, I wouldn’t say I was a Steve Jobs fanboy, but I knew Steve Jobs. And then when he went off to do NeXT, you know, he was kind of pushed out of Apple, we thought – we literally said, "We don’t know what you’re gonna do next, you might be selling, you know, bat guano to Eskimos. I know, it’s going to be exciting, we’re going with you," right?

So as he did NeXT Computers – and of course, Steve Jobs, for anyone who knows, was quite the showman, you know, not in a fluffy way there’s like, there’s no – there’s no steak with that sizzle. It’s like he knew what he was talking about. And he knew what people really wanted. He had a sense of style, right? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: It’s like, "Whatever you do, Steve is probably going to be good. We’re in." That’s what drove us, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Well, and NeXT was a really interesting company. I mean, as – so Apple ultimately bought NeXT.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Right.

KEVIN SCOTT: A whole bunch of the – of NeXT team, you know, like Craig Federighi, for instance, are still at Apple doing interesting stuff today, but you know, they – the – they had beautiful industrial design.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: There were two machines, so the NeXT Cube and the NeXT Station.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah,

KEVIN SCOTT: So one was a cube, and one was a pizza box, but it was – the, the back end of the operating system was UNIX. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: It had a really nice graphical user interface. They embraced object-oriented programming super early.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: So like they were innovating and doing a bunch of interesting things and putting a bunch of pieces together that are exactly the pieces that are together now that – you know, are the basis of what we use every day.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, yeah, exactly. And there was at that time, they introduced this thing called App Builder, which was the way of visually putting your application together by dragging and dropping, and all that sort of stuff. And today we go, yeah, of course. But at that time, it didn’t exist, right? So they were innovating in that sort of way. And Steve also did things like he said, "You should think of your …" 

He had a sense for how apps should work. "You should be no more than one click away from achieving some action." So he hated like, endless lists of menus, and all that sort of stuff. It was like one click, direct action is the way things should work, so you know, there were certain things about the platform Display PostScript, like you said, the networking model.

They have this thing called Speaker Listener, and it was a way of passing messages back and forth, even across the network. So yeah, there was a lot of innovation. And it allowed us to create apps that would come out and take two or three months instead of a year.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

WILLIAM ADAMS: It was quite literally that dramatic of a difference. And we even won – our company won an award. I can’t even remember what it was. It was the DB Expo way back then. We won an award for Best In Breed because of this database app stuff that we did. And it was because of object-oriented, you know, dynamic this, that and the other thing, and the way we connect things together. 

So yeah, it was – they had tons of Innovation that is now lasting, right? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: So yeah, that’s why – that’s why I did NeXT, because it’s like, "This is going to be where it’s at," you know?

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, and you know, it – NeXT wasn’t a super-successful company in the grand scheme of things.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Right.

KEVIN SCOTT: But it was a super-influential company.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, the DNA lived on, but they didn’t get the commercial success. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. So you were pretty prescient in figuring that out.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, I mean I did one more before I went off to Microsoft, which was the Be Operating System, BeOS –

KEVIN SCOTT: Which was another that was –

WILLIAM ADAMS: Another one of those things.

KEVIN SCOTT: Jean-Louis Gassée that was his company, right?

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah it was Jean-Louis Gassée, Steve Sakoman, I forgot, Erich [Ringewald] – I forgot Erich’s last name, but yeah –

KEVIN SCOTT: That was a brilliant operating system, like I never had one, but I always wanted a Be Box, like it was such a cool computer.

WILLIAM ADAMS: I still have one. I have one, down in the basement.

KEVIN SCOTT: Dude.

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, they were innovative in quite a few things. They were one of the first people to come out with a PC that was multiprocessing. It had two CPUs in it. And then they also had quite a lot of innovation in the UI, in terms of speed. This guy, Benoit Schillings, who later did Qt, did the UI for the BeOS. This other guy, Dominick [Giampaolo] – oh, what is Dominick’s last name? 

Anyway, they had this operating system that had – it was journaled, for one, so it was kind of crash proof. And they also had tagging, so you could attach tags to things, which made it really interesting. So, they did a lot of innovations. Of course, they didn’t win. They were – we were right there at that battle between is Apple going to buy NeXT or Be, and they bought NeXT. And that was the end of Be, essentially.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. So, how did you end up at Microsoft? 
 
WILLIAM ADAMS: So, as I was – I exited Be in, what was it, ‘96, I guess, maybe ‘97. And I was – because something happened there. It was like, ah, this is not a good place for me. So then, I was sitting around just kind of programming along, you know, compiling Linux and whatnot at home. And I had a friend at Microsoft, Chris Lovett, who said, “Hey, we’re working on this XML thing. You want to come join?” And I said, “That sounds interesting.” (Laughter.) 

So, I went up, did the interview, and was, like, yeah, okay, and this was right at the time where – it was 1998. So, recession is coming, .com bubble is inflating and about to burst. Microsoft is under investigation by the DOJ, about to be split up, you know, and I thought, that place is going to be – either they’re going down in flames, or they’re rising like a phoenix. Either way, it’s going to be a fun ride. So, I jumped off to Microsoft.

And it was also, I had a child. You know, these are my earning years. I’m 30-something. It’s like, well, this is my last chance to actually go get some dollars, you know, and not starve. So, I’d better go, you know, do that thing. So, I did. That’s how I came, because someone asked me to come. 
 
KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, and I think, again, that’s it – we, in a minute, are going to get to all of the DEI stuff and, like, inclusion and access. But, like, that is another thing: network matters. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Network matters, absolutely. Yeah. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Network, like being connected to people who not necessarily are, like, passing you opportunities, but just making you aware of what some of the interesting things are that you might not otherwise see, and, like, we want to work with you. Like, it’s just an amazing thing to have. 
 
WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah. And this Chris Lovett, I had met actually at Taligent, another Silicon Valley also-ran. And he was impressed with the work that I brought there from Adamation. And it was just that, right? It’s, like, he’s thinking, oh, that guy, William, he’s kind of interesting. Why don’t I give him a call? And then the opportunity is up to me to take it or not, right? It’s to impress or not impress. But yeah, network is super important. 
 
KEVIN SCOTT: So, tell us a little bit about the XML work that you did. So, it was, like, really central infrastructure, like, a thing that was – 

WILLIAM ADAMS: At that time. 

KEVIN SCOTT: At that time, that was very important to how the, you know, the sort of emerging network infrastructure was operating. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, I mean, XML, you know, the easiest way for – to put it in context is to say, well, HTML was important for the UI – the UI browser, right? XML was the equivalent for data transmission and sharing. Now, it went further and created things like SVG, which is the graphics format, and the Office – all their documents are actually XML formatted documents. They’re in a ZIP file, so you don’t realize it, you know, but they’re actually just XML. 

So, at the time, we were trying to do a couple of things, but primarily just being able to wrangle data, right, add some amount of structure and schema to data that otherwise is just kind of out there. And by structuring things with XML, you make it easier for intercompany communications or intracompany communications, and on and on. 

We went a bit too far. It got too cumbersome. Along came JSON, and now JSON’s that, right? But XML was super important at that time, right? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Well, and also in a bunch of subtle ways. I mean, like, one of the things that Microsoft did in Internet Explorer, like, with XML, adjacent to XML is, like, this thing called the XML HTTP request, which is – 

WILLIAM ADAMS: Oh yeah, that was the most important thing, because that allows you to program the Web, right?

KEVIN SCOTT: Correct. 

WILLIAM ADAMS: And now people, it’s like, well, you don’t even think about it. But at that time, yes, the HTML request was like, oh, this is different – (laughter) – because before that, there was no way to really, or at least, there wasn’t a real standardized way of saying, I’m going to call this function over there, right? So, yeah.
 
KEVIN SCOTT: Correct. And you know, again, just to pull back, like, this was the way where you could write an application in JavaScript that ran in your browser, that could then interact with something running in the cloud. 
 
WILLIAM ADAMS: So, we didn’t even have the cloud at that point, right? (Laughter.) 
 
KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, the cloud – yeah, nobody was calling it this silly name yet. 
 
WILLIAM ADAMS: Yeah, so it was the birth of that. It’s kind of funny, what you’re telling me is, like, well, there was the XHTML, you know, requesting. I’m like, yeah, no, we did that. (Laughter.) There’s so much history in there that it’s like, yeah, we did that, too. And we did that, and we did that.

Little known fact, I was granted a – after doing this XML stuff and some other stuff, my then-GM at the time, Dave Reid, said, “Hey, come up with something.” (Laughter.) So, he gave me free license. He said, “Pick your top six people, and go do something interesting.” And he had gotten some commandment from Bill Gates or whoever at the top, do something that helps us fight against Java at that time. 

And so, we went to do something that was really like, that would be hard for Java to do quickly, right? So, we ultimately came up with this thing, which is now called System.Linq. And I know you had Anders Hejlsberg on in the very beginning, and he talked about this. So, we worked with Anders and some other people, and came up with this way of changing your programming, such that your data types had nullable types. And we had things like lambda expressions, and there was – it was pretty easy to do database stuff, and XML integration, and blah, blah, blah. And that was something that Java couldn’t do easily. 

So, that was birthed out of this same set of people that were doing this XML work. They then prototyped the System.Linq stuff.

KEVIN SCOTT: It’s awesome, super cool. So, we’ll fast forward through a whole bunch of stuff. So, you and I first met when I came to Microsoft and was appointed CTO, and I was recruiting the first people into the office of the CTO. And I borrowed this concept that Bill Gates originated a long while back, which when he was running the company, he always had a technical adviser. And his technical adviser was basically, like, an avatar that he would send off into this org to go dive deep on things, and to come back and, like, help him make sure that he understood technically what’s going on, and that he had an independent point of view about the technical goings on inside of Microsoft, aside from what he’s being told by the teams that are working on stuff.
